doc.field: This collection consists of four film recordings on the Hudson Guild Neighborhood House created by Robbins Barstow in the 1940s. Barstow (1919-2010) received his master's degree in education and history from NYU in 1945. In the 1940s he and his wife Meg Barstow were group workers at the Hudson Guild Neighborhood House in the Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan.

This collection consists of four film recordings on the Hudson Guild Neighborhood House created by Robbins Barstow in the 1940s. Barstow (1919-2010) received his master's degree in education and history from NYU in 1945. In the 1940s he and his wife Meg Barstow were group workers at the Hudson Guild Neighborhood House in the Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan.

The collection consists of four film recordings created by Robbins Barstow in the 1940s. Youth and the Future and The Abbakadabba Coopno were both produced while Barstow and his wife Meg were group workers at the Hudson Guild Neighborhood House in the Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan. Everyone's Coming to the Guild contains scenes of a variety of people and kids from around the Guild House in Chelsea, and some Boys Club and Girls Club activities. Hudson Guild Farm consists of a series of short vignettes of different activities engaged in by the Boys and Girls Clubs and their counselors at the summer farm camp in New Jersey run by the Guild in the 1940s.

The films were transfered to DVD between the years 1999 and 2008. The DVD versions of Everyone's Coming to the Guild and Hudson Guild Farm include introductions describing the work which Barstow and his wife did at the Guild as group workers in the 1940s.

Robbins Barstow (1919-2010) was a Vermont native, champion of social justice, and moviemaker. He received his master's degree in education and history from NYU in 1945. His best known work, "Disneyland Dream" (1956), was inducted into the National Film Registry in 2008.
Donated by Robbins Barstow, 2008. The accession number associated with this gift is 09-003.

Access to audiovisual materials in this collection is available through digitized access copies. Researchers may view an item's original container, but the media themselves are not available for playback because of preservation concerns. Materials that have already been digitized are noted in the collection's finding aid and can be requested in our reading room.
